datafield.subfield: Spacetime Structure of the Black Hole Evaporation
Spacetime Structure of the Black Hole Evaporation
Withdrawn because the authors no longer think it is correct

We study a self-consistent solution of the semi-classical Einstein equation including the back reaction from the Hawking radiation. Our geometry is constructed by connecting flat space and the outgoing Vaidya metric at the locus of the shock wave. In order to prove that this is the self-consistent solution, we first show that the Weyl anomaly is canceled if we take the effects of the fluctuations of the metric into account. We further demonstrate that the Hawking radiation occurs even if the geometry has no horizon. Then, the energy-momentum tensor is found to be consistent with the semi-classical Einstein equation. Since our geometry has neither horizon nor singularity, all matters inside the black hole finally come back to infinity. Therefore, no information is lost by the black hole evaporation. Furthermore, we take into account the gray-body factor. We construct a stationary solution for a black hole in the heat bath and estimate the entropy. The entropy-area law is reproduced by the volume integration of the entropy density over the inside of the horizon, and the black hole can be treated as an ordinary thermodynamic object.

00002 Our model which is constructed by connecting the flat space and the outgoing Vaidya metric with a shock wave (left), and the Penrose diagram (right). The past event horizon ($r=r_h(u)$) and the past apparent horizon ($r=a(u)$) of the Vaidya metric which are described by dashed lines no longer exist in our model. The geometry has neither horizon nor singularity, so the ingoing wave comes back to infinity. The information loss dose not happen.

00004 The locus of the ray in the outgoing Eddington-Finkelstein coordinates (left) and in the Penrose diagram (right). The ray goes across the shock wave and reaches the future null infinity around $u_*$. The wave function of the outgoing ray having passed $r=0$ is $\tilde \phi_{\tilde u}(\omega')$ in flat spacetime and becomes $\phi_{u}(\omega)$ in the Vaidya spacetime. This change leads to the radiation. The shock wave $r_s(u)$ approaches $a(u)$ in the time scale $\sim a(u_{\ast})$, which is much smaller than the scale $\Delta u \sim a(u_{\ast})^3$ in which $a(u)$ changes significantly. Thus in the boxed region, $r_s(u)\sim r_h(u)\sim a(u)$.

00000 From the viewpoint at infinity, the black hole without the Hawking radiation is described by connecting flat metric and the Schwarzschild metric with the shock wave. We focus on the region which is enclosed by the box. The matters pile up to a thin region near the Schwarzschild radius and are accelerated by the gravitation. Then, they behave as a shock wave of light.
